last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>27739186
>So what do you feel got you to this place in life?
Well I always was overfed and always had a propensity for sugar. I also got weird signals from my mom as a kid who flipped between buying us a bunch of junk food and crying out of shame that she was a "horrible mother." I was always fatter than my older sisters though.
I started running in early high school and got below 200 pounds for a brief sweet time in my life. Then I transferred to a boarding school. I met a lot of great friends for the first time who I genuinely cared about, at my old high school I hung out with some bullies and neerdowells because they were the only people that did shit I was vaguely interested in like play counter-strike.
However I had access to a great dining hall at the new school, and my weight trend reversed. Back at home my parents had become bad at buying food at all, and the high school cafeteria was awful (I'm a picky eater), so I was basically forced to eat less. But I could eat a lot again at this new school.
At the same time my running fell off. I don't for sure remember why. I had two friends who were starting a running club but I didn't like to go with them. It may have been because I couldn't keep up with them since I was still overweight, and so I was ashamed. I did often go to the university gym (the boarding school was on a state campus), but never quite often enough to build stamina progress like I had been doing before.

Freshman year of college, my life got harder. Most of my friends went to a competing state school focused on STEM while I went to one with a very strong business program. However, I quickly learned that most business students are not compatible with my personality, it's like a dumping ground of high school preps and jocks to drink and fuck for four years.
I made some friends outside there with an early gen ed class, but they were a toxic group. They even had a superiority complex against me for being a business major, it was really weird. I wasn't studying something 'real' or academically rigorous in their eyes, and business was problematic because capitalism, exploitation, etc. College student shit I guess. Overall, it was like the boarding school I went to had people who were more mature at a young age, while these college people were still mentally high schoolers.
And then covid-19 hit second semester. Friend groups fell apart, online classes and isolation began. I had a roommate at least so I had a reason not to just pig out.
For the last two years I have lived alone. I have a car now so I don't even have to walk to do groceries, so I'm sedentary. I can buy as much pop and junk food and fast food as I want and nobody can see me for me to feel shame. I become aware of how terribly I live when I feel aches and pain in my body, but it's not a constant enough state of mind to override my cravings when they get strong. When I think about finding food, it's like other things don't matter. Somewhere in the back of my head I know there's consequences for my body but that's not audible until I've already eaten.

Dr. Frankenstein hated his teachers, his peers. Everyone was a fuckin' retard, making so many complex sciences to abate death, to treat disease, to slow it. He settled for nothing less than one final strike, he obsessed over Agrippa, Paracelsus. Alchemy and the esoteric. He wanted to not waste time with death's symptoms. He wanted to defeat it entirely.

His monster was a clean slate. Ugly, visibly affected by being of trauma, but inside he had innocence. He had passion and hope to be a part of the world. But the world took one look at him, and screamed at him. Yelled at him, Excluded him and exiled him, even beat him and shot him. And he gave them a monster to be afraid of.

That's it, that's all that social skills are, just saying things that are relevant at the moment. Then once you learn more about these people, you just talk about what you learned about and share new information you gained with other people. You learn that someone is studying political science, then you speak to someone studying law, you tell the second guy you know someone studying political science and ask if it's similar. You meet a person that skydives, then you learn a person that likes bungee jumping, you bring up the person that likes skydiving and ask repeat some things that first person said. All social skills are is just remembering things other people have said to you, the anecdotes about their daily lives they said to you and then repeating them at other people. Social skills are all very easy, it's just memorizing stories that are relevant to situation

last_replies.com: A lot of my motivation comes from the fear of waking up one day to a bad life. One day we will be 40 years old and when that day comes for me I want to not be poor, alone and unhealthy. In the future you will have more shit to pay for and it will cost even more than beforehand, so it makes sense to get a good job now. In the future your body will naturally degrade, you'll lose muscle mass and not be as resistant to stuff like cancer, so it makes sense to get /fit/ now. In the future your parents will die and your friends will all be too busy with work and families, so it makes sense to form close bonds with people and to find some sort of family of your own.
